title: Egalitarian but not Equal: Sectoral Wage Formation and Gendered Wage Differentials
descriptions:
The proposed project, "Egalitarian but not Equal: Sectoral Wage Formation and Gendered Wage Differentials," aims to investigate the gendered nature of collective bargaining in the metal and nursing sectors in Germany, Norway, and Sweden. With global and European average gender pay gaps standing at 20% and 13% respectively, this project, named WAGE, seeks to address the disparities in wage formation between genders.

Using ethnographic research methods, the project will compare and synthesize existing histories of collective bargaining and the gender pay gap in the selected countries. It will also uncover and analyze the daily practices in collective bargaining rounds that lead to wage increases in the male-dominated metal sector and the female-dominated nursing sector. Furthermore, the project will document and explain how actors within these sectors relate to wage norms and gendered wage differentials.

By shedding light on the mechanisms that perpetuate gendered wage differentials within specific sectors, this research has the potential to inform policy interventions aimed at reducing the gender pay gap. Ultimately, through a deep dive into the intricacies of sectoral wage formation, the project seeks to contribute to a more equitable and just labor market for all individuals, irrespective of their gender.

Through a rigorous examination of the interplay between collective bargaining and gendered wage differentials, WAGE seeks to contribute valuable insights to the field of gender studies and labor economics.
